The bucketing only creates new module when the bucket_key is met first time. It's pretty much the same thing you want. The input shape is not a big issue. It depends on how you defining and parsing the bucket_key. For me, I'm using a string as bucket key,with label length,and lstm length concated. 
``` python
    def sym_gen(bucket_key):
        label_length, lstm_length = bucket_key.split(',')
        lstm_length = int(lstm_length)
        label_length = int(label_length)
```

thank you @sergeykolychev for the great work! I'm not a perl programmer (actually used it 10 years ago when I was at Microsoft), so I can only ask some general questions. 

1. Is there a good reason to make the module named `AI.MXNet` instead of `MXNet` directly? AI refers a general field, while MXNet only focuses on deep learning. 

2. How can we generate documents which can hosted on http://mxnet.io

3. What's the procedure to update the perl module if updates have been made to the python package, most likely document changes and small fixes? 

4. Will you be able to maintain the perl package in the future?

5. It seems you updated the submodules, can you please roll back the changes, e.g. reset the changes in `.gitmodules` located in the root directory

Just write the net,then use your parameters to initial the net,simple code like this:
``` 
     def net():
            a = mx.sym.Variable('data')
            conv1 = mx.sym.Convolution(data=a,kernel=(3,3),num_fliter=64,name="conv1")
            flatten = mx.sym.Flatten(data=conv1,name='flatten')
            fc = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=b,num_hidden=4,name="fc1")
            return fc
```
this will return a net symbol, then you can use this code to load your parameters :
```
     def load_checkpoint(file_name):
            save_dict = mx.nd.load(file_name)
            arg_params = {}
            aux_params = {}
            for k, v in save_dict.items():
                tp, name = k.split(':', 1)
                if tp == 'arg':
                     arg_params[name] = v
                if tp == 'aux':
                     aux_params[name] = v
            return arg_params, aux_params
```
Now you get the arg_params,then use the params initialize you net,see `mx.mod.Module` for detail. if you want to fix some parameters ,just add the param's name to fixed_param_prefix.   
example code was in `/mxnet/example/rcnn/train_end2end.py` line74 -line 85, 102 -105,141 -145, hope it helps.

Hello @mli 
1) This interface is intended of course to be used by Perl programmers, who use CPAN https://metacpan.org/search?size=500&q=AI  and accustomed to certain namespace conventions.
AI:: is well established namespace that includes multiple subjects including interfaces to C NN libraries, NN libs implemented in Perl only or something completely unrelated to NN. There's no need to establish new namespace and I believe that current name will generate more visibility for this extension and appropriate.
2) I write my code while embedding docs via standard Perl documentation markup, see http://perldoc.perl.org/perlpod.html , that can be automatically converted to MAN, PDF, HTML or any other format conceived.
That said, the package is still alpha and I am currently concentrated in reaching full parity with Python interface, so the POD is not yet fully Perlish, there's a lot verbatim taken from Python doc.
I plan to rewrite all of that after I am done with Python => Perl translation.
As well I am consciously writing this interface with look and feel of original Python interface, keeping all method names and parameters in sync, so Python docs and examples will be usable in Perl context as well. 
3) (and 4) I am volunteering to be the maintainer of the perl-package for the foreseeable future and will keep the module updated and in sync. Also I am sure, there'll be more people in Perl community interested in helping me in coming years as ML gets more popular.
5) Will do.
Thank you for writing this software, I have a lot fun working on this project.

```
def gen_model_mx(my_params):
    data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
    net = mx.sym.Convolution(data, name='conv1', kernel=(11,11), num_filter=96, stride=(2,2))
    net = mx.sym.BatchNorm(net, name='bn1')
    
    model = mx.mod.Module(net)
    
    data_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data=np.zeros((1,3,127,127)))
    model.bind(data_shapes=data_iter.provide_data)

    arg_params = {
        "conv1_weight": mx.nd.array(my_params['conv1f']),
        "conv1_bias":  mx.nd.array(my_params['conv1b']),
        "bn1_beta":  mx.nd.array(my_params['bn1b']),
        "bn1_gamma":  mx.nd.array(my_params['bn1m']),
    }

    aux_params = {
        "bn1_moving_mean": mx.nd.array(my_params['bn1x'][:, 0]),
        "bn1_moving_var" : mx.nd.array(my_params['bn1x'][:, 1]**2),       
    }

    model.init_params(arg_params=arg_params, aux_params=aux_params)
    model.save_checkpoint(prefix="mymodel", epoch=1)
```

Hi all, an update on this issue:

I've tried to change the definition in tensor_blob.h from 

`Tuple()=default;`

to

`inline Tuple(){}`

and that seemed to do the trick (for me at least). However, I have no idea if this might impact something else in the long run.

Diving a little deeper into this issue. This is my current understanding of memory sharing:

* python land: BucketingModule
  * BucketingModule has a _curr_module member that is passed to module.bind
  * initially this member is the default module, however each call to self.switch_bucket will set it to a different module
* C++, GraphExecutor class
  * GraphExecutor::Init gets a shared_exec that is the executor of the shared module pass to module.bind
  * GraphExecutor::InitDataEntryMemory gets the data_pool_ member of the shared executor
  * data_pool_ is a vector of ndarrays
  * After GraphExecutor::InitDataEntryMemory is called data_pool_ will contain all ndarrays borrowed from the shared executor and also potentially new ndarrays it created. Important: As no all shapes fit necessarily it might have fewer entries than the original data_pool_ coming from the shared executor.

So with the above one potential problem occurs when we first see a small bucket and then a larger bucket subsequently. This is because in this scenario _curr_module in BucketingModule will point to the small bucket, which has a data_pool_ that is smaller than the data_pool_ of the default bucket module.

Given this I tried to modify BucketingModule to always pass the default module as shared module (as my assumption was that the default module will always occupy more space than any given module). Now this actually works, but only when turning off all memory optimizations (NNVM_EXEC_ENABLE_INPLACE=false NNVM_EXEC_MATCH_RANGE=0). If they these are not turned off we still allocate new memory in InitDataEntryMemory as the shapes across buckets don't match up anymore.

I'm glad I'm not the only one who has this issue. I still need to check whether this is problem does not exist in 0.8. One potentially interesting thing is that in 0.8 the [allocator](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/v0.8.0/src/symbol/graph_memory_allocator.cc) has access to the shared_mem_, whereas in [nnvm](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/src/pass/plan_memory.cc) it doesn't actually when planning the memory.

It seems the params' shape doesn't change, the input and output of siamense_net is fixed,because the input of siamese_net  is  the output of ROIPooling layer.

Here is the main code of MutableModule, it checks whether the input shape changes, if yes, bulid a new module and bind it :
``` 
    def forward(self, data_batch, is_train=None):
        assert self.binded and self.params_initialized

        # get current_shapes
        if self._curr_module.label_shapes is not None:
            current_shapes = dict(self._curr_module.data_shapes + self._curr_module.label_shapes)
        else:
            current_shapes = dict(self._curr_module.data_shapes)

        # get input_shapes
        if data_batch.provide_label is not None:
            input_shapes = dict(data_batch.provide_data + data_batch.provide_label)
        else:
            input_shapes = dict(data_batch.provide_data)

        # decide if shape changed
        shape_changed = False
        for k, v in current_shapes.items():
            if v != input_shapes[k]:
                shape_changed = True

        if shape_changed:
            self._curr_sym = self._sym_gen(data_batch.bucket_key)
            module = Module(self._curr_sym, self._data_names, self._label_names,
                            logger=self.logger, context=self._context,
                            work_load_list=self._work_load_list,
                            fixed_param_names=self._fixed_param_names)
            module.bind(data_batch.provide_data, data_batch.provide_label, self._curr_module.for_training,
                        self._curr_module.inputs_need_grad, force_rebind=False,
                        shared_module=self._curr_module)
            self._curr_module = module

        self._curr_module.forward(data_batch, is_train=is_train)
```
example/rnn/cudnn_lstm_bucketing is a new example
